item.title: EARTH DAY NETWORK CAMPAIGNS
item.description:
EARTH DAY NETWORK CAMPAIGNS

Earth Day Network works year-round on projects, programs, and campaigns that support environmental conservation, environmental protection, climate activism and advocacy, and advancing the green economy. Our education work focuses on efforts to green schools — from energy efficiency upgrades to improving school food — and supporting educators with resources to teach and inspire the next generation of environmental leaders. Our conservation and greening efforts include planting trees to reforest environmentally critical areas of the globe and increase the urban tree canopy, and protecting clean air and water. Our advocacy efforts focus on engaging local leaders and global citizens of all ages and from all walks of life with campaigns: to end plastic pollution, to protect our species, to act on climate and advance clean energy, and more.

ALLGREEN SCHOOLSENDANGERED SPECIESREFORESTATIONPLASTIC POLLUTIONGREEN CITIESCAMPAIGN FOR COMMUNITIESCLIMATE CHANGE

PLASTIC POLLUTION

Together we can tackle this global crisis!


GREEN CITIES

Let's make the shift to green cities together to live more sustainable lives. From green buildings to the economy, around the world we need to make a change. 

CAMPAIGN FOR COMMUNITIES

Get local with solutions.

CLIMATE CHANGE

The time for real action and progress to address the climate change crisis is now.

ALL

View all Earth Day Network campaigns.

GREEN SCHOOLS

Our commitment: Climate literacy and healthy schools for all.

ENDANGERED SPECIES

Protect endangered species around the world.

REFORESTATION

Earth Day Network works to reforest our planet through on-the-ground tree planting projects and building strong communities that protect and care for trees.

item.title: General Plan Elements
item.description:
The General Plan is a dynamic document consisting of several elements, as well as the Land Use Element, which consists of the plans for each of the City’s 35 Community Plan Areas.

It is approved by the City Planning Commission and adopted by the City Council.

What’s New!

We have recently adopted two new elements of the General Plan: the Mobility Plan 2035, the Transportation Element of the General Plan, and the Plan for a Healthy Los Angeles, a new Health and Wellness Element of the General Plan.

Up to date information about the Mobility Plan 2035 and the adopted Plan for a Healthy Los Angeles can be found at the links below.

  • Plan for a Healthy Los Angeles
  • Framework Element
  • AIR Quality Element
  • Conservation Element
  • Housing Element
  • Noise Element
  • Open Space Element
  • Service Systems Element/Public Recreation Plan
  • Safety Element
  • Mobility Element

item.title: VCAP VIRTUAL community action Planning
item.description:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/7hs1v354gp0j5kw/lesson%20Plan-rev1.pdf?dl=0

Download framework. 

Andrew,

I believe our total conversation today fits this eight part framework.   Alignments into this framework address Place Based Development. A criteria of Community Benefit Agreements.  COMPLIANCE AS CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. 

Just referring to these Chapters show linkage points needed to build, support ,maintain,  and operate Livable Cities 

1. Land Division as Value
2. Infrastructure collective cost, individual profit
3. Culture as Collective Value
4  Culture Exchange Place Typologies Church Schools, Parks, Clubs, Market Place.
5  Nature as a system
6. System Theory 
7.  Communication Exchange and Capture Web 2.0
8. Project proposal,  Time, Resources,  Scope.

item.title: Crossrail: Building a Virtual Version of London's Elizabeth line - The Development of the BIM Environment - Crossrail Learning Legacy
item.description:
The same is needed for water and electricity and biodiversity and effects of 3500 trees in Watts.   Stop the Spin, build a data model.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Michael Rendler <michael.rendler@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, Jan 3, 2019, 11:00 AM
Subject: Crossrail: Building a Virtual Version of London's Elizabeth line - The Development of the BIM Environment - Crossrail Learning Legacy
To: Stanley Washington <swash57@gmail.com>, Brad Carson <brad@jobscreatepeace.com>, Jacquelyn Dupont-Walker <jdupontw@aol.com>, Jacquelyn Badejo <jtsbadejo@gmail.com>, Katherine Duncan <w5cclv@gmail.com>, William Wells <william@asteamvillage.org>, Arnold Gordon-Bray <arnoldngb@gmail.com>, Cory Henry <coryhenry6@gmail.com>, Jorge C. Mata <MataJC@email.laccd.edu>, Tina Quigley <quigleyt@rtcsnv.com>


https://learninglegacy.crossrail.co.uk/documents/crossrail-development-bim-environment/

Mr. Washington, 

As per our discussion today, Virgin Rails,(from England) Nevada, Las Vegas high speed rail, and #onboarding the project Crossrails and our Jails, to Rails, to Trails project as part of Watts Rising model with VCAP Virtual Community Action Planning and Opportunity Zone /Section 3 INTEGRATION. 

I have copied our collaborator in Kansas City , Missouri part of HUD Envision Center pilot city where I will be explaining this integration, January 17, at their Regional Envision Center Summit .

Building a Comprehensive Data Model, for Social (Sustainability = Diversity) and Environmental (Biodiversity Models) Justice.
